quoteFirst: I remember another ball given at Day’s Mill, near Brunswick, early in 1861, which I attended, and left
quoteLast: . Later, a man named Price, without law or authority, as he lived in the city and was not an officer thereof, gathered a squad of roughs and went to the Mill and surrounded the ballroom. They ordered all who had passes to come forward, and they were allowed to go free.
title: The New Man: Twenty-nine years a slave, twenty-nine years a free man
author: Bruce, Henry Clay, 1836-1902

quoteLast: . When I arrived at Dunbar I got some accounts of him; Mr. Brodie had left that place in a post-chaise. At Newcastle I was informed that he had taken the “Flying Mercury” post-coach to York; and I was afterwards informed that he had continued in it till he came to London.
title: Trial of Deacon Brodie
author: Brodie, William, 1741-1788 [Other]; Roughead, William, 1870-1952 [Editor]; Smith, George, -1788 [Other]

quoteLast: The Boche replied with a counter barrage, and he had a very fair range on our outpost line. In five minutes the shells were ripping the tops off the trees all around, and the air grew acrid from the bursting lyddite.
title: The history of Company B, 311th Infantry in the World War
author: Colonna, B. A. (Benjamin Allison), 1894-1983 [Editor]; Gardenier, David, 1896-1965 [Contributor]; Peter, Charles [Contributor]; Stiles, Bert W. [Contributor]; White, Tracy S. (Tracy Stutts), 1892-1932 [Contributor]

title: Love Potions Through the Ages: A Study of Amatory Devices and Mores

quoteFirst: We have no hesitation in saying that they were utterly unfit for the habitation of human beings, and further that they were never designed for permanent residences. The mode of erecting these shanties was as follows: The planks were sawed the right length in the town of Vallejo or Benicia, in the afternoon of the day, and at nightfall were loaded upon a cart.
quoteLast: the team would start for the intended settlement, reaching there about one or two o'clock in the morning. Between that hour and daylight the house would be erected and finished.
title: Personal reminiscences of early days in California, with other sketches
author: Field, Stephen J. (Stephen Johnson), 1816-1899; Gorham, George C. (George Congdon), 1832-1909

quoteFirst: Amelia was now living very near my house in town, and, as I really wanted to see the handsome young Campbell, I availed myself of her invitation to a small party before I left town. I ventured to return home from her house at
quoteLast: , alone, because the distance was very trifling; but the moment I had left my sister's door I observed a tall, dark, and somewhat, as I thought, wild-looking young man following me. I felt unusually alarmed, and trusting to the lightness of my heels I began to run as fast as I possibly could.
title:
The Memoirs of Harriette Wilson, Volumes One and Two
Written by Herself
author: Wilson, Harriette, 1786-1846

quoteFirst: The 3d, 4th, 5th, and 6th of April, a continued storm of wind and rain; a dreadful sea, and very cold weather. We lowered our yards, furled our courses, and lay by for the most part under a mizzen and mizzen-stay sail. The 3d,
quoteLast: , a raging sea took us on the larboard quarter, where it stove in the quarter gallery, and rushed into the ship like a deluge. For some time it laid the ship down upon her side; but she providentially righted again, though slowly; it threw down and half drowned all the people on the deck, broke one of the straps of the main dead-eyes, and snaped a mizzen and puttock shroud.
title: An historical account of all the voyages round the world, performed by English navigators, vol. 2 of 4
author: Henry, David, 1710-1792 [Editor]

quoteLast: having been two days on the road.
title: Fifteen Months in Dixie; Or, My Personal Experience in Rebel Prisons
author: Day, W. W. (William Worthy), 1839-1921
